item.title: Altar Location (Talisman)
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

In PHP you used “==” to compare strings so when I started coding Java I also used “==” for string comparison.

Read full topic

item.title: Altar Location (Talisman)
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

Using == on objects actually compares the memory addresses of these objects, so it should only be used to determine if two object references are equal.

I created an illustrative example to show this.

Example:

public static void main(String[] args)
{
	String str1 = "kryptix_needs_to_learn java";
	String str2 = "kryptix_needs_to_learn java";		
	System.out.println(str1 == str2);
	System.out.println(str1.equals(str2));
		
	str2 = new String("kryptix_needs_to_learn java");	
	System.out.println(str1 == str2);
	System.out.println(str1.equals(str2));
}

Output:

true
true
false
true

At first str1 and str2 point to the same object, that’s a static optimization, because the content is known at compile time. Then str2 is updated to contain the same data again, however this time it points to a different object and using == returns false.

Read full topic

item.title: Altar Location (Talisman)
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:7, topic:395476”]I’m not really sure exactly what the += operator does/calls, and whether it checks for null or not, a simple test would tell you:

String bob = null;
bob += “tom”;
System.out.println(bob);

If that doesn’t throw errors, then += must be smart enough to just initialize it to a new string if it is null. I know you couldn’t call a function on it though (ie, bob.equals would throw an exception).[/quote]+= creates a string buffer to concatenate the string, which given null or blank parameters works just fine

item.title: Altar Location (Talisman)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I’m not really sure exactly what the += operator does/calls, and whether it checks for null or not, a simple test would tell you:

String bob = null;
bob += “tom”;
System.out.println(bob);

If that doesn’t throw errors, then += must be smart enough to just initialize it to a new string if it is null. I know you couldn’t call a function on it though (ie, bob.equals would throw an exception).

Read full topic

item.title: Altar Location (Talisman)
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

public static String locateAltar(int playerX, int playerY, int altarX, int altarY) { String string = "The talsiman is vibrating uncontrollably, you're at the altar!"; if((playerX != altarX) || (playerY != altarY)) { string = "The talisman pulls towards the "; string += (playerY != altarY ? (playerY < altarY ? "south" : "north") : ""); string += (playerX != altarX ? (playerX < altarX ? "west" : "east") : ""); string += "."; } return string; }

Read full topic

item.title: Altar Location (Talisman)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

What is the exact code that produced that though? Two things I can think of could have happened:

public static String locateAltar(int playerX, int playerY, int altarX, int altarY) {
        String string = "";
       
        if (Math.abs(playerY - altarY) > 0)
                string = (playerY < altarY ? "south" : "north");
       
        if (Math.abs(playerX - altarX) > 0)
                string += (string == "" ? "" : "-")+(playerX < altarX ? "west" : "east");
               
        return "The talisman pulls towards the " + string + ".";
}

Would probably work at least with the Sun compiler right now, but not because it should work, but because of a compiler optimization which produces code that looks like this:

public static String locateAltar(int playerX, int playerY, int altarX, int altarY) {
        String compilerGeneratedStaticString = "";
        String string = compilerGeneratedStaticString;
       
        if (Math.abs(playerY - altarY) > 0)
                string = (playerY < altarY ? "south" : "north");
       
        if (Math.abs(playerX - altarX) > 0)
                string += (string == compilerGeneratedStaticString ? compilerGeneratedStaticString : "-")+(playerX < altarX ? "west" : "east");
               
        return "The talisman pulls towards the " + string + ".";
}

But you can’t always count on it being optimized like that, which is why you should use .equals.

Also, with code like this:

public static String locateAltar(int playerX, int playerY, int altarX, int altarY) {
        String string;
       
        if (Math.abs(playerY - altarY) > 0)
                string = (playerY < altarY ? "south" : "north");
       
        if (Math.abs(playerX - altarX) > 0)
                string += (string == "" ? "" : "-")+(playerX < altarX ? "west" : "east");
               
        return "The talisman pulls towards the " + string + ".";
}

That doesn’t throw a nullpointerexception because you can compare ‘null == “”’ legally, but after you change it to .equals, you can’t call a null.equals without throwing an exception.

So a combo of dumb luck and compiler optimizations might have saved you.

Read full topic

item.title: Altar Location (Talisman)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It would work fine until someone was exactly east or west (because string is always set to ‘south’ or ‘north’ otherwise), but when they were, it should throw a NullPointerException (and crash your server if it wasn’t caught)

As to the ==, it appeared to work to, since it was always false and always printed a ‘-’ as expected because you probably never tested it from exactly east or west.

That’s why bugs like that are so messy, they work for years until someone finds the exact combo that breaks them.

Read full topic

item.title: Altar Location (Talisman)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You can’t compare a string value in java with ==, it doesn’t work like you think, so that needs changed. Also, you could simplify it a tad more with this (same operations, less code duplication):

                string += (string.equals("") ? "" : "-")+(playerX < altarX ? "west" : "east");

Come to think of it, you also need to set String string = “”; in the beginning, because as it is right now the value is null, so before it printed straight ‘west’ or ‘east’ it would throw a nullpointer exception.

So, in the end, it needs to look like this:

public static String locateAltar(int playerX, int playerY, int altarX, int altarY) {
        String string = "";
       
        if (Math.abs(playerY - altarY) > 0)
                string = (playerY < altarY ? "south" : "north");
       
        if (Math.abs(playerX - altarX) > 0)
                string += (string.equals("") ? "" : "-")+(playerX < altarX ? "west" : "east");
               
        return "The talisman pulls towards the " + string + ".";
}

Read full topic

item.title: Altar Location (Talisman)
item.dc:creator: @Kryptix Kryptix
item.description:
@Kryptix wrote:

A few people have PM’d me about this so I thought I’d release it. There’s no error handling and giving it the wrong data will break it but providing the altars are located sensibly it will work fine (as it does on RSCEmulation). This won’t work at different map heights (underground and upstairs) but all the altars on RS2 are on the main ground level so it wasn’t programmed to be like that.

[code=java5]public static String locateAltar(int playerX, int playerY, int altarX, int altarY) {
String string = “”;

    if (Math.abs(playerY - altarY) > 0)
            string = (playerY < altarY ? "south" : "north");
   
    if (Math.abs(playerX - altarX) > 0)
            string += (string.equals("") ? "" : "-") + (playerX < altarX ? "west" : "east");
           
    return "The talisman pulls towards the " + string + ".";

}[/code]

Read full topic
